subject: Re: [junit] Is Junit-based testing REALLY possible for commercial software development ?
msgSnippet: #: J. B. Rainsberger changed the world a bit at a time by saying (astral date: 2/10/2006 4:49 AM) :# ... I tend to agree with the this approach, but I use it
messageBody:
#: J. B. Rainsberger changed the world a bit at a time by saying (astral date: 2/10/2006 4:49 AM) :#
> Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
>> - Using debuggers less might be a good thing *if* the developers find
>> bugs faster. I have seen quite a few TDD enthusiasts choose not to use
>> debuggers for dogmatic reasons ("because I read it in a book") and then
>> spend hours writing tests or even println's trying to reproduce a
>> mysterious
>> bug that a breakpoint would have caught in a few minutes.
>
> While I agree with your overall point, I'm surprised by this. If a
> debugger could have found the problem in a few minutes, then why did it
> take hours to write the tests? If I have to write 1 test per frame of
> the stack trace, that's maybe 15-20 tests.
>
> Now, if it takes hours to write 20 tests, then they must not be very
> good TDD practitioners; and if they're good TDD practitioners, then the
> code is easy to test and it wouldn't take hours to write 20 of them.
>
> My general approach is this:
>
> 1. Reason about the problem. Try to write 2-3 tests.
> 2. If #1 doesn't find the problem, launch the debugger and step until we
> find the frame of the stack where the problem occurs.
> 3. Find the values of the input to that method, then drop out of the
> debugger and write the test. It fails.
>
> Voila. As you say, a /good/ marriage between debugger and tests.

I tend to agree with the this approach, but I use it quite in the other order:
- reason about the problem; set some breakpoints; fire debugger; find the stack where the problem occurs
- write the test => fails
- fix the code => test passes

I have tried both approaches, and for me (I underline this) it worked better.

./alex
--
